Expectation1: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation1: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A severe hurricane has left hundreds of people homeless in the community, and the mayor has asked the nun to help organize a major relief effort.
Story: I stared at the blinking red lights on the control panel, the hum of the machines growing louder, more urgent. They’d missed their last service window, and now the temperature gauges were edging into the danger zone. If I didn’t act soon, the whole line could shut down, costing the factory precious hours and risking my reputation as a reliable repairer. My hands itched to grab my tools, to get to work cleaning and tuning, but my phone buzzed again—another message from Sister Maria. The hurricane had left so many without homes, and the mayor was pleading for help. As a nun, I was expected to lead the relief effort, to comfort the frightened and organize food and shelter. My heart ached for the families huddled in the church hall, but the machines demanded my attention too. I felt torn, the weight of both uniforms pressing down on me, each role pulling me in a different direction. I closed my eyes, caught between the whirring of engines and the cries for help, unsure which duty to answer first.
